abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, and the institutional development
            impact substantial. Lessons from the project experience
            support the conclusion that a series of single-tranche
            adjustment operations, anchored through a medium term reform
            framework to reforming states, can be an effective
            instrument to support reforms in India. From the effective
            project design, policy lessons indicate that frequent, and
            regular monitoring can lead to greater awareness of the
            fiscal position, and risks, taking into account realistic
            tax targets. However, improved forecasting of state output
            is needed to make fiscal targets as a percentage of output,
            more reliable, while public account financing should be
            reduced over time, since financing from the public accounts
            can distort the deficit numbers, and reduce budgetary
            transparency. From the power sector perspective, it is
            suggested that in light of electricity consumption being
            subsidized, particularly when tariffs are de-linked from
            consumption, regulation of power supply to subsidized
            sectors is crucial as a transitional measure to restore the
            sector's financial viability, even though one of the
            aims of reforms is to let go of the need to limit power
            supply. In turn, the creation of a power sector regulator,
            complemented by integrated functions among the regulator,
            utility, and government should ease the reform process.
